'''Ellen Forney''' (born March 8, 1968) is an American [[cartoonist]] and educator. She is known for her autobiographic comics, which included ''I was Seven in '75'' , ''I Love Led Zepellin'', and ''Marbles''. She teaches at the [[Cornish College of the Arts]].
== Career == Forney received a B.A. degree from [[Wesleyan University]], where she majored in psychology.<ref name="seattlepi2006" />
In the 1990s, she produced the autobiographical strip ''I Was Seven in '75'', which ran in Seattle's alternative-weekly paper ''[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lambiek.net/artists/f/forney_ellen.htm |title=Comic creator: Ellen Forney | Lambiek Comiclopedia |publisher=Lambiek.net |date=2007-02-16 |accessdate=2013-08-02}}</ref> She self-published a collection in 1997 with a [[Xeric Foundation]] grant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sequentialtart.com/archive/feb00/forney.shtml |title=Ellen Forney - "I'm Okay, You're Okay!" (vol III/iss 2/February 2000) |publisher=Sequential Tart |date= |accessdate=2013-08-02}}</ref> A complete collection was published as ''Monkey Food'' by Fantagraphics in 1999.
In 2006 she published ''I Love Led Zeppelin'', which collected comics she had done for various newspapers and magazines, and included collaborations with [[Margaret Cho]], [[Kristin Gore]], [[Camille Paglia]], and [[Dan Savage]].<ref name="seattlepi2006">{{cite news| url=http://www.seattlepi.com/books/280352_forney08.html | work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer | first1=Winda | last1=Benedetti | title=Seattle cartoonist Ellen Forney embraces our oddities | date=August 7, 2006}}</ref> It was nominated for an [[Eisner Award]] as Best Reality-Based Comic.<ref>[http://www.comicsreporter.com/index.php/your_2007_san_diego_con_update4/ The Comics Reporter<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://public.vwc.edu/news-a-events/recent-news/1045-acclaimed-cartoonist-ellen-forney-speaks-about-words-and-pictures] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720111209/http://public.vwc.edu/news-a-events/recent-news/1045-acclaimed-cartoonist-ellen-forney-speaks-about-words-and-pictures |date=July 20, 2011 }}</ref> In 2007 she illustrated [[Sherman Alexie]]'s young-adult novel ''[[The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian]]'', which won the [[National Book Award]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/entertainment/20110203_Philly-linked_artist_adds_life_to_award-winning_book.html |title=Philly-linked artist adds life to award-winning book |publisher=Philly.com |date=2010-10-26 |accessdate=2013-08-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first= Jonathan |last= Hiskes |title= Northwest Fiction Rooted in the Region |url=http://crosscut.com/blog/crosscut/18709/ |work= |publisher= ''[[Crosscut.com|Crosscut]]'' |location= Seattle, WA |id= |pages= |page= |date= December 10, 2008 |accessdate=2011-08-20 |language= |quote= }}</ref><ref>http://www.thetowerlight.com/2011/10/qa-with-cartoonist-ellen-forney/</ref> In 2008 she published ''Lust'' which adapted personal ads from ''The Stranger'' into illustrated/comics form.<ref>{{cite news|first=Jen |last=Graves |title=New in Books |url=http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=511046 |work= |publisher=[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]] |location= |id= |pages= |page= |date=February 13, 2008 |accessdate=2008-02-29 |language= |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080216024024/http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=511046 |archivedate=February 16, 2008 }}</ref>
Her [[Graphic novel|graphic memoir]] ''Marbles: Mania, Depression, Michelangelo, and Me''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Marbles-Depression-Michelangelo-Graphic-Memoir/dp/1592407323/ |title=Marbles: Mania, Depression, Michelangelo, and Me: A Graphic Memoir: Ellen Forney: 9781592407323: Amazon.com: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-02}}</ref> addressed her experiences with [[Bipolar Disorder]].<ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/18/bipolar-disorder-ellen-forney_n_5823138.html</ref> It was published by [[Penguin Books]]' Gotham Books imprint in November 2012.<ref>[http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/authors/profiles/article/54604-the-bipolar-cartoonist-ellen-forney-s-marbles.html The Bipolar Cartoonist: Ellen Forney’s ‘Marbles’], Publishers Weekly. By Grace Bello. November 05, 2012. Retrieved November 17, 2012.</ref><ref>David Low, [http://newsletter.blogs.wesleyan.edu/2012/11/15/forneybook/ Forney ’89 Writes Graphic Novel on Bipolar Disorder], The Wesleyan Connection (Wesleyan University), 2012-11-15. Accessed 2012-11-17.</ref>
In 2016, Forney produced two murals, ''Crossed Pinkies'' and ''Walking Fingers'', that were installed in the new [[Capitol Hill station|Capitol Hill light rail station]] in Seattle, Washington.<ref>{{cite news |last=Graves |first=Jen |date=December 9, 2015 |title=How Ellen Forney Got the Right Pair of Hands for Her Capitol Hill Light Rail Station Mural |url=http://www.thestranger.com/visual-art/features/2015/12/09/23247443/how-ellen-forney-got-the-right-pair-of-hands-for-her-capitol-hill-light-rail-station-mural |work=The Stranger |accessdate=August 9, 2017}}</ref>
Forney's 2018 book ''Rock Steady: Brilliant Advice from My Bipolar Life'' is a graphic self-help guide, published by [[Fantagraphics Books|Fantagraphics]].
She is based in [[Seattle]], [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]].
==Personal life== Forney is bisexual.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.curvemag.com/Curve-Magazine/Web-Articles-2012/Page-Turners-Ellen-Forney/|title=Page Turner: Ellen Forney|work=[[Curve (magazine)|Curve]]|date=November 7, 2012|first=Grace|last=Bello}}</ref>
